description.en:
The course is going to be divided into two approximately equal halves. In the first half, basic principles of machine learning and deep learning will be introduced. We will discuss topics such as how to design an appropriate training data set, what components neural networks are built from, what algorithms allow us to train them efficiently and so on. We will also consider some successful deep learning architectures such as ResNet, LSTM, Transformer, VAE, GAN and others, and look at both what kinds of problems they can solve as well as what makes them very effective at doing so.
In the second half of the course, the attention will shift to specific applications of deep learning models in the broad field of molecular biology. We will look at how deep learning revolutionised protein structure modelling, including famous models such as AlphaFold. We will consider the use of deep learning in protein engineering, protein interaction prediction, drug design and others. A common theme throughout the course will focus on ways in which we can represent biological molecules as data structures amenable to deep learning, and how lessons from computer vision, natural language processing and reinforcement learning help advance molecular biology.
In addition to taught lectures, the course will contain both computer practical and journal club elements.

grade_evaluation.et:
Your assessment will be based on a project that you should conduct and present at the end of the semester. A jury will evaluate your presentation.
100% final presentation.

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)
